On August 28th we will start the school year using the Distance Learning Instructional Model. This means all students will be learning at home.

will help us with social distancing in the classrooms, cafeterias, hallways, and buses when return to face to face instruction.

Turner County Schools has had employees that have tested positive for COVID-19 or have had symptoms. They are in quarantine. Following guidelines, we have determined a number of employees who have had direct contact with them. We have made calls to inform those employees. They should self quarantine for 14 days. If we have additional employees to test positive, we will be making additional calls to any who have had direct contact. The Department of Health will also be contact tracing confirmed cases.
Because of these events, Turner County Schools will be postponing Pre Planning until August 17th. We will be sending out additional safety guidelines and plans before we return. The first day for students will be August 28th. We will start school with all students using Distance Learning (online)Instruction. All other plans for the restart of school will be announced as soon as possible.
During this time, I urge all everyone to wear a mask in public, stay home as much as possible, and follow safe procedures.

Thank you,
Craig Matthews, Superintendent

I have been given a task by the Turner County Board of Education to study the appropriateness of our rebel mascot for Turner County High School. The link to the survey is under the News and Announcements. Paper copies are available at the Board of Education office. It will be available until August 5th, 2020. Please use the survey to give your opinion. Comments to this post will be deleted.
Thank you,
Craig Matthews, Superintendent

"I am deeply grateful to State School Superintendent Richard Woods, the Georgia Department of Education, superintendents, and parents for keeping us informed and helping us make the right decision for our students," said Governor Kemp. "Throughout this process, we will continue to seek the advice of public health officials, school leaders, and families to ensure the health and safety of the educational community. As we approach April 24, 2020, we ask for continued patience and flexibility since circumstances may change, but we encourage families to stay strong and follow the guidance of federal, state, and local leaders in the weeks ahead."

The University System of Georgia and Technical College System of Georgia will remain closed for in-person instruction through the rest of the semester since students have already transitioned to all online learning.

Fourth graders from Turner Co. Elementary School took a field trip to the Destination Ag program at the Agrirama in Tifton. The students learned about different plants that grow in the different regions of Georgia, flower arranging, economics, bees, and much more.

The students entered the writing and art contest through Destination Ag where the students wrote and illustrated about how agriculture positively impacts our world and what agriculture means to us.

Kaydence Joiner won the contest and received a $100 gift card and her homeroom teacher, Kayla McMahan, received $500 to purchase classroom supplies.

We are so excited and proud of Kaydence and her teacher, Mrs. McMahan! CONGRATULATIONS!!! Kayla McMahan Eva Grayer Joi

Monday, January 23, 2017 2:00 PM Turner County Schools will resume school tomorrow, Tuesday, January 24, 2017. However, buses will not be able to travel on dirt roads for several more days. We are asking parents that if you live on a dirt road and would like to meet your bus at the intersection of the hard road and dirt road, all buses will stop at those intersections at their normal pickup times. If your child is unable to make it to school, all schools will allow ample time for students to make up work they may have missed.
For faculty and staff needing additional time to address family needs, please know that Turner County Schools fully support your decisions. Substitute personnel will be called to help out at the schools. We do not want you to worry but to understand that Turner County Schools gives you our full support in your endeavors to get your life back to normal as much as possible. We pray that everyone stays safe during this time of recovery.
Posted 1/23/17 2:00 pm

The Turner County Board of Education is accepting applications for 6 Custodian positions.

Minimum Qualification Requirements:

¬∑ Be able to perform general labor and maintenance, including sweeping and cleaning.
¬∑ Must be flexible with different shift work hours.
¬∑ Ability to operate walk behind floor scrubber and other powered equipment.
¬∑ Can clean and maintain all areas of the building, fixtures, furniture and equipment.
¬∑ Ability to lift 25+ lbs.

Custodians will be paid on an hourly rate plus benefits that include enrollment in the Public School Retirement System (PSR) and an option for Health Insurance.

Applications may be picked up at any school or at the Board of Education Office. Applications must be returned to the Board Office by noon on Thursday, March 24, 2016.

post_text: Seventh grade teachers Amber Smith Stephens and Eva T. Joiner recently attended a STEM (Science, Technology Engineering and Math) Conference. Today they are visiting Turner County Elementary School to redeliver that training to the teachers there. They will be demonstrating how to use new features on the Georgia Public Broadcasting/Discovery Education sites. They will also show how to use Plickers. Plickers is a powerfully simple tool that lets teachers collect real-time formative assessment data using only a set of cards and a single cell phone or tablet. Here are some pictures of Plickers in action at Turner County Middle School.
